description:
Another one of Alana's cool bookmarks!

Seems like someone (Peter Richards, designer, and George Gonzalez, sculptor) got a bright idea to install 25 PVC pipes at the edge of the ocean so that the waves would naturally enter them and make some sounds = natural music!  This unusual art installation is connected with the Exploration and was dedicated in May 1986 to the late Frank Oppenheimer, its founding director and fundraiser. 

Cris, Alana, and I drove to the very end of Yacht Road, past a small sign, and parked in a reserved stall for a military officer. It didn't look like they were having any functions at the time and we wouldn't be there for long.

The views along the walking path were fabulous. We saw Alcatraz, downtown San Francisco, and the Golden Gate Bridge!  In the water, we saw a couple of sea lion heads bobbing up and down!

It's too bad that we went when it wasn't high tide. We had a great time anyway and Cris could hear some music!  Let's go again during high tide!
author: Nadine C.

description:
One word. Unique. In conjunction with the Exploratorium these artists created a granite hidden treasure that sparks the imagination. This lovely short walk to a truly one of a kind place in all of San Francisco, deserves credit.

I enjoy the walk out, the smell of the sea air. Vista Skylines to the south, sand bars, little beaches, Bay Views, Alcatraz, and the wonders of the Pacific wildlife. At the end you reach a little park made of old building capitols and abandon gravestones. Emerging from them are PVC Piping that meets the waters edge. At special times of the day as the tides change, different pipes are slapped by water and a sound is carried to the seating area. Brilliant. Sit and enjoy this heavenly symphony.

It is worth the walk and trip to point to view it. I love this place. Extreme chill zone where people from all over the world visit.
author: Thomas B.

description:
Hmm. First, like our ancestors mention come to the Wave Organ during high tide. Basically the rougher the seas, the better the music! Something Jack Sparrow once taught me! Having said that it's hard to predict the tides, or the surf report, unless you're an avid surfer, or use a thing called "google", but hey, it's ok, I came over not knowing the ocean conditions, too. And yes, I surf & google lol. 

The Wave Organ is kinda sorta on the cusp of being urban legend. Some hate on it, some adore it. Others, like me, is somewhere in between. Yet, I'm sure if I did my tide homework I would have had a better experience. The location is in the Marina District on Yacht Road. Since it's where the yachts park, parking can be anyone's guess, unless you're Thurston Howell the III, therefore I'd suggest biking or bus/walking it. To me, half the journey was checking out the sites walking over. It's not that far from Marina Blvd. and the views of Golden Gate Bridge & Fort Mason... simply breathtaking!

I had nothing to do on a quiet Sunday, so decided to do some urban hiking. After walking up to Coit Tower, the Maritime Park, and other spontaneous stops along the way, I decide to take a walk to the Wave Organ. If walking or biking I'd suggest taking the coastal route through Fort Mason. Thank me later! On weekends the Marina can get super busy and crowded, so take your time and watch traffic of all sorts coming and going. Once you reach Yacht Road it's only a short walk over. Keep walking...

Finally, you'll see it at the very end of Yacht Road. Basically large pipes protruding from the ground. Maybe something from the pages of One Fish, Two Fish, Red Fish, Blue Fish. Pretty rad actually. Someone as curious as you, or as lost as you, will also be there. For me, I had the honors of sharing time with tourists speaking French, Mandain, and Hindi! Probably more locals during the weekdays, but don't expect a solo trip with Sir Elton John! 

All in all, I'd recommend the Wave Organ, but I'd also suggest coming during higher tides if possible for the fullest effect. Lower your expectations too... although it's considered urban art gifted to San Francisco by the SF Exploratorium back in 1986, it's basically 25 PVC organ pipes that make funny gurgling sounds. The Wave Organ is dedicated to Frank Oppenheimer, the founding director of the Exploratorium, who sadly passed away months before construction began. Another tidbit, is that most of the foundation is salvaged from the old pre-civil war cemetery, Laurel Hill. Perhaps there's some truth to the urban legend here... 

Ohh, lastly, after sitting in the middle of all those tourists I found out the best way "to listen" to the waves was closing my eyes, ears to the pipes, and simply chilling! Maybe this is what's it all about!
author: Eric R.

description:
Go at high tide. Check the tide calendar: http://tides.mobilegeographics.com/calendar/year/5546.html

When you've planned accordingly, come sit, relax, and enjoy the experience! It's such a unique way to listen to the ocean's music!
author: Heidi D.

description:
I'm glad I decided to come out to the Wave Organ after living here for years and never visiting. I took my friend who was visiting and had heard good things about it. The walk over from the parking lot took about 10 minutes, but I can't complain because the views were incredible. We were lucky enough to go on a clear and sunny day so it was beautiful next to the bay, otherwise I don't know if I would be so positive. 

We got to the Wave Organ itself and it was a little disappointing - just a collection of different pipes. We didn't really hear any noises, but it was a nice place to relax and look out at the city and enjoy the water hitting the land. 

I looked into it a little more afterwards, and it seems like you have to go during high tide to actually hear the 'music of the sea,' which we must have missed. Regardless, like I said, I'm glad I went but I think I'll give this a pass next time, and I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to it.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Before I get started, I want to mention that you need to go during high tide for this to be effective so, check the tide calendar! 

Not sure why people are hating on the Wave Organ as it's a unique art installation that is quintessential SF. I mean, who else would put tubes in the ocean in hopes of creating a musical instrument...San Francisco, right?! 

This past weekend while on a jog in the marina area I remembered this funky little landmark and decided to head that way. There weren't any tourists out there which I thought was interesting but, it made for a nice little private symphony. Some of the "organ" pipes were going while others weren't in full swing due to the mid tide. 

If you're in the area it's worth the walk but, I wouldn't make a day of it :)
author: Benjamin F.

description: Don't bother. We thought it would be a lot cooler than it was and ended up disappointed. It's just some metal tubes that slightly amplify the sounds of the water that you would already hear.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: I should've read the yelp reviews before I came because we definitely didn't go on a high tide day, but regardless the view from here is breathtaking. It's amazing how the pipes are installed into the rocks. If you are in the area I would walk here and check it out. The day we went there was a sailing competition going on so it was fairly busy. Come and take cool pics. You can say you've been there and done that.
author: Trinh V.

description: This was a fun sight to see and listen, music by the sea (do not go at low tide). Also, make sure you combine it with a walk on the Marina and The Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Melody K.

description:
Not far from the Golden Gate Yacht Club is the Wave Organ, an acoustic sculpture constructed on the shore of San Francisco Bay in May 1986 by the Exploratorium.

Constructed utilizing stone pieces salvaged from the demolition of the Laurel Hill Cemetery in San Francisco, Exploratorium artist in residence Peter Richards (conceived and designed the organ) and sculptor/mason George Gonzales are credited for the work.

The area features 25 PVC organ pipes dedicated to the late Exploratorium founding director Frank Oppenheimer, Oppenheimer was responsible for the fundraising efforts for the Wave Organ.

The pipes interacts with the waves from the bay and if people put their ears on the end of the pipes, they can hear the effects of the waves (depending on the level of the tide).

It was a bit of a bummer to see this work have graffiti in certain locations of the Wave Organ.  And I'm not sure if the city of San Francisco or the Exploratorium maintains it by removing the graffiti.  And people have left their litter underneath some areas, which was also not cool!

If I have any advice for anyone who is interested in visiting the area, you may want to bring good walking shoes as it may be a far walk depending where you are coming from (I walked from the Fort Mason Center and I thought it was close but took a little over an hour just to walk there).

Also, remember that it can get windy and cold, so prepare for that as well.

But the Wave Organ is definitely an interesting area to visit and you can get good photos, especially during the weekend when the yachts and boats are out, around the location.

And for those who love workouts, especially from Fort Mason Center or the parks, the fact that you ran/walked that far to the Wave Organ is quite a bit of an accomplishment.
author: Dennis A.

description:
What a discovery it is! On 10/8/2017, when I was heading back to San Francisco from Sacramento, I upon a special place of this interesting hidden gem located within in the Pacific Ocean called, "Wave Organ." This sculpture (made back in 1986) conveys the sounds of ocean waves crashing by hearing various of sound effects at different stations of organs. Tides are pouring in giving various of sounds like rumbling, gurgling, hisses etc. no matter how big or small it is.

Located far east from the Golden Gate Yacht Club, this centerpiece was part of a possible construction until it got halted and salvaged because they decided to keep the stones forever of the former Laurel Hill Cemetery. The organ designer and exploratorium, Peter Richards created this centerpiece by resembling the designs of Wave Organ with the help of sculptor George Gonzales to complete this project. As of today, it still lives here giving it a fantastic panoramic view of the Alcatraz, Golden Gate Bridge, Fort Mason, Crissy Field even the Marina Greens.

I was ecstatic that I was enjoying the whole view of Wave Organ. It's much calming and relaxing as I was roaming around for few hours by showing various of yachts, boats, cruise ships and ship porters as well as sea creatures, seagulls and airplanes. Fascinating!

Parking at Wave Organ can be challenging to park. You can park at the nearby surface street parking nor the parking lot if it's available. Since walking is a good option, riding a bike is the best choice to trek to Wave Organ faster in half of time. Also, you can carpool, ride sharing or public transportation easier without the hassles and gimmicks.

In the end, Wave Organ is the most fantastic historic landmark that I've ever visited in years right in the north west side of San Francisco. A well visit for all ages from young to old! My rating: 5 solid stars.
author: William L.

description: It's a great photo opp, but we didn't hear any amazing music. The sea was too calm. But it seems like a very "San Fransiscoian" thing to check out and you will walk away with beautiful shots.
author: Christy C.

description:
Definitely a unique landmark/structure to visit, with some pretty decent views of the Golden Gate. Also some cool sounds from the organ pipes if you're lucky! Its quite a walk from the Palace of Fine Arts, but you can find parking by the yacht club. 

I wouldn't put this on the top of your list of must-visits in SF, especially if you're only there for a day trip. I personally didn't find the sounds coming from the organ pipes to be that impressive, but that's just my opinion. My friends were into it. I did however enjoy the relaxing stroll all the way down to this structure and it did look nice!
author: Justin K.

description:
I think it got its name because you take the time to visit this stone sculpture expecting an organ, you will wave fifteen minutes goodbye.

Walking the road from the parking lot was the best part of the experience because of the view of the Golden Gate and the waves crashing up and over the rocks.  Otherwise it's merely a PVC pipe cemetery.

As for the organ, I was expecting music but it sounded more like when you put your ear on a huge dog's stomach after he's eaten chocolate and half a shoe.  At best, it sounds like someone with prostate problems peeing on a wind chime.
author: Glen N.

description: There's only 2 in the world so far and this is one of them. Awesome place to relax. It's a bit dirty and sounds funny but it's still cool. Far in one of the marinas, I found it because I was looking at the one in Europe and saw on a post there's one on SFO. You can walk to it from downtown but it's a far walk. It's beautiful though .
author: Diana B.

description: Who had that idea was a genius!!!! Some how is not wind around the organ and people were there with wine and chilling. Perfect to go at night. But be aware like everywhere in San Francisco has homeless and the creepy one so bring a friend and keep alert. Their is no security and the naval club close at night. But besides that you can totally stay there for hours hearing that fantastic noise made by the ocean. Very peaceful and calm. I got the app to know when the tide was high to be able to hear it and was a great check list :)
author: carla a.

description:
What more can I say then this is definitely wonderfully wacky!

The wave organ is basically a bunch of pipes placed underwater with one end open so you can listen to the waves hitting these pipes.  You do need to get yourself near the openings in order to hear them.  Oddly fun, and likely not something that I would suggest a visitor with a short timeframe.  But if you have the time to go, do it, again, it is wonderfully wacky.
author: Phil B.

description:
First, I have to say that I absolutely love any destination like this that allows you to get away from the tourists stuff and just sit back a minute and enjoy.

The idea of the pipes is brilliant and the volume and depth of the sounds is greatly dependent on the tide. If you go at the wrong time you will be like, "Uh, what's the big deal?" If you go at the right time, you will not want to leave.

I was disgusted by all the graffiti scrawled across the rocks but if you overlook that, you will see the real beauty. Yes, the views are stunning, but to me the beauty was in the stopping to listen.
author: Chris D.

description: We came at low tide so I will definitely give it another try during high tide. We didn't hear much but the idea is neat. The area is pretty and it's a nice spot to walk to and just relax.
author: Danyelle H.

description:
Splish Splash

The Wave Organ is one of those peculiar places unique to each San Francisco neighborhood. This one is built in the affluent Marina District by the shore of the bay just past the Golden Gate Yacht Club. It's got an ocean front view of the bay, Golden Gate Bridge, Angel Island and Alcatraz. 

This structure was constructed on a strip of man-made land in 1986 by the Exploratorium when it was still located by the Palace of Fine Arts on Baker St. It's at at the very tip of the the harbor and I would suggest parking between the St. Francis Yacht Club and Golden Gate Yacht Club. You can park on Marina Green, but there's no land bridge that connect you from the parking lot straight to this location. Unless you don't mind walking at least half a mile or more do get to this place and you are not in a rush and it could a nice leisurely stroll, especially if you bring your four-legged family member along. 

I remember exploring this place when I was a kid back in the 80's and it reminded me so much of an old Roman city ruin with all the stones and marbles stacked on top of one another. Years later, I find out that most of the marble used was salvaged from an old cemetery in the city. Gee, I wonder if some of those inhabitants disturbed by the move came along and moved her permanently. 

The organs are made from PVC pipes that connects to the bottom of the bay that creates different sounds of splashes and splishes when the waves hits these instruments. Suffice to say that the San Francisco Symphony is safe from their jobs, but you do get to hear a free "musical" orchestra with an assist from Mother Nature. I'm sure the little ones will get a kick out of it, unless they have their phones with 'em and are hunting for Pokemon. If I see one playing Pokemon here, I might grab their device and throw it in the bay. Hearing it plop in the water will be music to my ears. 

If the sound of the pipes are not doing it for you, at least the panoramic views of this place is gorgeous. I think I saw the Death Star in one of the photos.
author: John G.

description:
Who knew that such a small landmark would attract so many people from all walks of life?

The Wave Organ is a quaint little spot near Fort Mason and the marina in San Francisco where you get a "musical" experience with the water. Essentially, there are a number of tubes sticking out of the water where you can put your ears next to them and hear the waves. 

If you can stand the possibility of being splashed or better yet, pooped on by the seagulls, I encourage you to come here and relax. It's so peaceful at the Wave Organ. Even with tourists around, everyone is quiet and patiently listening to the melodies of the wave organ/

tl;dr this is one of those hidden spots in SF that people don't talk about. Don't let it be lost in the wild. Come check it out!
author: Bryan W.

description:
A piece of Europe is immediately what I thought as j was walking the path towards this "island" of reflection and tranquility.

Passing the yacht clubs and slowly away from the heavy foot traffic, I was certain this was what I was waiting for.

Utilizing the waves this fun location creates organic music that is pumped out into these large pipelines. There's a few man-made steps and benches but it's is so peaceful! I found myself there for over an hour just looking at the beautiful views. 

Highly suggest using the bathroom before and having snacks/drinks on you if you get hungry.

I can't really put into words how much this spot meant to me. But it's great for reflection purposes.

& yes it's a poke gym but don't disturb those who are trying to make the most of this experience.
author: Tomas R.

description: Whoever thought of the wave organ was a genius.  There are stone pipes along the stone benches that plays sounds of the ocean waves. (Almost like what you hear on a conch shell, but on a bigger scale).  The quality and volume is 100% on the ocean tide.  So, best time to come visit would be during high tides.  Kind of feels like playing musical chairs jumping from 1 pipe to another searching for the best one.  On top of being a pleasing place for the ears, your eyes are provided with views of the Golden Gate Bridge, Angel Island, and Alcatraz too.  The Wave Organ is a nice place to visit and relax if you are in the area.
author: Dang L.

description: My wife and I recently visited San Francisco for the first time and really wanted to check out the Wave Organ. We went during high tide as recommended, but we were pretty disappointed. The organ is heard by putting your ears up to a series of different pipes. Some pipes sounded similar to a conch shell. Others basically sounded like a flushing toilet. I would skip this landmark, especially if you're short on time.
author: Larry H.

description: Cool, but not what I thought. I had seen the ones on Croatia and thought it would be similar. I'd still recommend a visit.
author: melisa w.

description:
I don't really get this thing.  I saw a YouTube video about the Wave Organ being this great invention and even calling it a 'phenomenon'.  The sounds of the organ displayed on the video were loud and gurgling and it looked like a natural sort of organ powered by waves. I've heard it's supposed to be better during high tide but I've never heard anything whenever I've been there.

If you are into acoustic design or weird art you might like it but other than that I'd give it a pass.
It's definitely a beautiful walk with great views of Alcatraz but if you are looking for something interesting and different it falls short of expectation.
author: Joan W.

description:
This place is a lot smaller than it looked in the pictures. I imagined something big to explore like lands end, but it end up looking like a kiddie play structure. I thought the idea was very cool, but I honestly did not hear anything different and was kind of disappointed that I went out of my way for it. 
The area itself is pretty to look at since you can see most of sf and the bay. It's at the very end of a path and you have to walk down a few steps to get to it, but really there's not much of it. I went around 7ish in the evening and it got pretty cold there so make sure to bring a jacket if you decide to check it this out. 
I wouldn't recommend going out of your way for this, but if you're in the area it's nice to check out. Just keep your expectations low.
author: Renee Y.

description:
It's a pretty view but the pipes make no sound. It was disappointing and the other people that were there when I showed up literally had their ears to the pipes. 

Also, parking is a mile away. It would have been nice for a low-key picnic with a pretty view but since we weren't aware/prepared it was a bummer.
author: Abby M.

description:
A hard to find extension of the usual touristy path to the Golden Gate Bridge makes for a great 360 degree view of the city: golden gate bridge on the left, angel island and alcatraz ahead, FiDi on the right and the marina behind. Sit a little, or play on the secluded beach with your kids.

Great beach playing for kids and their parents! And for tourists wanting a great view!
author: Regina D.

description:
A great place to hang out and take a walk with friends!

There should be plenty of parking if you come here at the right time. We came on a Saturday for the sunset (windy and cold!!) and found street parking, but it looks like there was a lot more parking in the lot on the way.

It was a nice walk down the beach and great views.
author: Michael T.

description:
Really neat. Glad I found it. I wish I would have read the reviews before I parked (on the wrong side as mentioned below). Still it was a nice day and the walk was nice. I have never seen anything like it and I can bet I never will. 
Make sure you listen to each pipe. Each one sounds different.
author: Angelic M.

description: Go at high tide, or at least at kind of high tide. The sounds are amazing, and it is a surreal experience sitting by the water amidst the sounds of the water and the "organ pipes". Its history is interesting too. Nice, chill place to rest (bring a jacket)
author: Bonnie M.

description: It saddens me to report that this place has graffiti all over it. I will say that I was impressed with the views this place has to offer of the Golden Gate Bridge. I was pleasantly surprised to find how easy it was to find parking, even on a beautiful Saturday afternoon. The Wave Organ itself was disappointing.
author: Katy C.

description:
I can't give a proper review of this because we were there during the airshow. Although the planes above were very loud, there were moments where no planes flew and we tried to hear the sounds of the wave organ and we couldn't quite hear it. 

However, I do think that it is a great place for a view of the San Francisco bay as well as the Bay Bridge. 

I definitely want to try to come another time to hear these wave organs!
author: Kristy N.

description: Fun to visit because you can now say you know where it is.... As for sound? Meh!
author: John J.

description:
This is a neat installment at the end of a lonely pier behind the yacht club. If you're riding across the Golden Gate Bridge, it's an easy stop across from the Palace of Fine Arts and about a 5 minute bike ride. It's hard to find, because there's no signs and (when we went) no people gathering, but just go out as faaaar as you can and it's there. It's really neat, and during high tide you can hear the waves through the many different pipes sticking out among the pier. 

A fun and different site to see in San Francisco, defintely make this a stop.
author: Melinda R.

description:
The address is correct but it'll lead you to the parking lot along Marina Blvd and Scott St.
And from there, you have to walk less than a mile. But if you are lazy, we noticed that there is parking along Yatch Rd or Lyon Street heading towards the Wave Organ.
If you're around the Marina, check this place out! Quite interesting.
It's an acoustic sculpture and there are pipelines that interact with the waves.
So it's better during high tides.
It's near Crissy Field and it has a perfect view of the GG Bridge.
Depending on the time and day, it can be breezy so bring a jacket.
author: Laramae E.

description:
This place was a little hard to find but that's what make adventures more fun.

The Yelp address will take you directly across from where you need to be but from that address there's no way of getting across. We parked passing the light house looking structure past a building that I believe is for Yacht club members to eat.

Very and windy but beautiful view! Honestly the pictures make it look way bigger than it is but it does have a small beach that we saw quite a few of dog owners with dogs.
author: Natalia T.

description:
Hugely helpful tip, GPS your way to the Golden Gate Yacht Club. There is parking down there by the small brick lighthouse. Then you walk out on the jetty to find the Wave Organ. Really get down and put your ear near the pipes. Each one sounds a little bit different. 

The views of Alcatraz, Angel Island, Golden Gate Bridge, and of downtown San Francisco are incredible out there. It can get windy, but its a wonderful walk.
author: Kari G.

description:
Cool idea but didn't work for us. WTF? Regardless, it was still worth the time to have the adventure to see it. We added it to one of the stops on our family bike ride. 

From Wikipedia:
The Wave Organ is an acoustic sculpture constructed on the shore of San Francisco Bay in May 1986 by the Exploratorium. Through a series of pipes, the wave organ interacts with the waves of the bay and conveys their sound to listeners at several different stations. The effects produced vary depending on the level of the tide but include rumbles, gurgles, sloshes, hisses, and other more typical wave sounds. The structure incorporates stone platforms and benches where visitors may sit near the mouths of pipes, listening.

The Wave Organ is located at the end of a spit of land extending from the Golden Gate Yacht Club. The stone pieces used in its construction were salvaged from the demolition of the Laurel Hill Cemetery in San Francisco. Exploratorium artist in residence Peter Richards conceived and designed the organ, working with sculptor and mason George Gonzales.

There is a panoramic view of the city across the narrow channel into the St.Francis and Golden Gate yacht clubs, bounded on the left by the Fort Mason piers and to the right by a towering eucalyptus grove bordering Crissy Field. The Marina Green park lies directly across, just beyond a stone sea wall.[citation needed]

The Wave Organ includes 25 PVC organ pipes and is dedicated to Frank Oppenheimer. Oppenheimer was the Founding Director of the Exploratorium, led the fundraising efforts for the Wave Organ, and he died seven months before construction started.
author: David S.

description:
I was looking for something interesting and free to do in San Francisco and I found it here. This is a gorgeous piece of both art and sound located at the very tip of the islet, just past the yacht club. There are loads of pipes that lead from the SF bay up into your ears as you sit on a built in bench or crouch down to the ground to hear the waves. It's a very peaceful spot in the city that not many seem to frequent. 

It is by the bay itself though, so bring a jacket against the cold wind, bring a book if you've got some time to kill, and enjoy the wonderfulness that is San Francisco.
author: Emily G.

description: We were there at low tide so it was hard to get the full experience but it was beautiful and so clean. The few sounds we did hear were so cool. Wish we times it better!
author: Lacey Q.

description:
I wrote a great review and made the mistake of using a bad character that I caught too late after clicking. 

Now my great review is gone. 

So there that is. Thanks yelp. I guess the save button is just  for kicks and giggles.
author: Januarie Y.

description: Cool little area at the end of the jetty. Look much larger in photos than it actually is. It was low tide when I went so I didn't here anyhow from them. The structure is pretty cool but had more fun looking for crabs on the rocks and walking on the sanded area around the wave organ. I wouldn't go out of your way to see it.
author: Christine V.

description: You don't hear anything but glugs and splashes from the inside of pipes that make people think this is some kind of "music". The view is nice I guess, but this is definitely not musical at all.
author: Alexis E.

description: Maybe the waves weren't strong enough that day or the organs weren't maintained properly, the organs weren't working when I arrived.
author: Rocky L.

description:
This is such a cool place to visit! It's a little walk from the parking lot (which is free). My friend (who I came here with) was the one who told me about this place. It's on the side passed the yachts area and the country club. 

When we got there, I was a little disappointed because it was smaller than I thought. It was cool though. There are benches made out of the Wave Organ where you could sit and just enjoy the view! You can see the beach from the Wave Organ and it's such a pretty sight! 

It was a little disappointing when we realized that the Wave Organs really work during high tides, which is usually during the afternoon so we were a little too early for that. 

But overall, I do recommend this place because it's super cool! I'll be back next time to hear those waves clashing into the organs!
author: Wendy Y.

description: The best time to hear the "organs" is when the tide is coming in. Check online beforehand or get really baked until you hear Ariel start singing under da sea
author: Jose O.

description:
There is a lot of hype buzzing around this cool hidden gem, as it only attracts those willing enough to  walk all the way down the length of the Golden Gate Yacht Club trail to encounter it. If you are driving, go down Yacht Road and be careful where you park in the lot, some spaces are marked only for members. After that, just keep walking straight to the end of the road to find intriguingly unique cement sculptures. While they look very abstract and formless, during high tide their true purpose can be heard, bellowing out different octaves of a mimicked "organ" sound. Of course this is only functional during high tide, so planning and timing to hear it in its full potential can be difficult, making it frustrating to walk all the way down and not hear anything- that's how the hype burned out for me..
However it is still a cool find and you'll have fun exploring through all the different cement fixtures!
author: Kyrie S.

description:
This is one of the coolest things to do in San Francisco, but it seems like a lot of people don't even know about it!

If you're in the area of the Marina Green or Crissy Field (or even Fisherman's Wharf), this is an easy place to visit.  If you're facing the San Francisco Yacht Club, you turn to your right and walk down until you get to the end of a jetty. Then you'll see incredible views and "music" that's generated by pipes that go down into the ocean.

There's a sign that explains that the "organ" is best heard during high tide or the full moon, but even if you're out there when the sound isn't as clear, it's a nice place to just sit and listen to the waves and take in the views.
author: Kimberly B.

description: I was a little disappointed actually. We got there in the morning on a Monday and while there were hardly any people around so that was a good thing. We parked right in front of the wave organ not realizing we had to walk a good distance around to get to it. I don't mind walking and we got to get some nice pictures of the Golden Gate along the way so that was good too. When we actually DID get to the organ itself,  was sad to see graffiti all over the place and no sounds like I was expecting or hoping for. We didn't know it was better to wait for high tide to get the musical effect. duh. still, it was a pretty view and something to check off the "must see" list for our 1st time in SF.
author: Vicky H.

description:
I must call BS on "music" coming from the Wave Organ.

I'm not sure what I was supposed to hear. I'm still not. I figured the water would push air through a narrowing fluted pipe much like the bellows of a pipe organ. The result would be similar to a grunting organ or at worst, someone with a sinus problem wheezing to breathe.

What I ended up hearing were a couple water-gulping chugs and feedback like holding a seashell to the ear. You can easily recreate this lackluster experience at home by buying 4-inch PVC drainage pipe from Home Depot and dipping the end into a bucket of water. For more entertainment, tap the side of the pipe with a stick to pretend you're a member of the Blue Man Group.

Built in 1986, some write that it is no longer working, but that's hard to believe because it was restored in 2010. Some write to come at high tide for the greatest effect. We came at 3:00pm - which we confirmed the next day at the Exploratorium it was close to high tide. Just looking at the height of the water compared to the breakwater, the level was high, but it didn't seem to create much sound. The hum of seaplanes flying around the bay created more noise than the Wave Organ.

That location has a wonderful view, but there are plenty of those in San Francisco and what makes the city one of the prettiest in the world. If you still dare to go, park next to the St. Francis Yacht Club and take the half-mile walk to the peninsula.
author: Brian U.

description:
The wave organ is a great mini-excursion for anyone looking to get away from the Fisherman's Wharf crowds. I walked straight over from the last cable car stop, and while admittedly it was a bit of a hike, the view was great and sound effects were pretty cool. 

Tips: You have to walk WAY out on Yacht Road past the St. Francis Yacht Club to find it on the last little stretch of rocks. Definitely try sitting on the bench and giving yourself a few minutes to take in the acoustics from the overhang, and don't be afraid to get down on the ground to check out the hard-to-reach pipes! Some of them were the best.
author: Rachel H.

description:
It was a delightful day.

I can't remember when I was first treated to the Wave Organ.  I know it was a long, long time ago.  Another lifetime, really.  And from the steps and benches that haven't changed I could look back over at what could have been.  The color of the sky fit my occasional mood.

The Wave Organ is the Yin to Chestnut Street's Yang.  At the end of the jetty that points at Fort Mason from Bay it doesn't look like much more than a jumble of rocks.  Which is excellent, for as if it did more of what stays on Bay would fill the jetty, and it's that absence that takes you out there in the first place.

The Organ is made of pipes run to different depths into the space between the tides.  At high tide they're mostl all submerged.  The pressure of the wave action moves water up and down, forcing air in and out of the end nearest your ear, making wave music.  The stones are from a cemetary that used to live where Laurel Village lives now.  With luck the inhabitants were disinterred and redeposited someplace safer.  That, or this explains why the LV Starbucks always felt a little odd.

Early morning is the best time to come if your preference is just you and your solitude.  Weekday afternoons are nice as well.  At night I'd expect you could find somebody to stone you, if that was your pleasure.  Parking is ample along Bay and in Fort Mason and a few public spots near the volleyball fields.

Do go.  I really think you'll like it.
author: Markus N.

description: Talk about amazing works of art! This is such a neat place to visit! I suggest before visiting, you check out the times for the tide, because then you can really get the feel for the organ made by the waves! You will have to take a bit of a walk to get out to the organ but it is amazing and worth the walk. Also, depending on the weather, you will probably want to have a jacket or something to keep the chill off. Enjoy the music and maybe even leave a love note in the holes hidden around for the ocean to take away at high tide!
author: Tina S.

description: No sound was coming from any of the pipes, we went during a full moon and in the afternoon as suggested for best sound. Boo!
author: Deidra R.

description:
This is a really weird and wonderful place. Don't expect lots of sound unless you are there at high tide on an inclement day. Do expect beauty and wonder. Romantic, contemplative, original. Worth it.
One of the most wonderful things about it is that much of the stone was reclaimed from an old cemetary. Wow.
author: laura r.

description: Not sure why this place is called the Wave Organ (is it meant to have music!?), but it's a really nice gem tucked away in the Marina District. Small but lots of interesting pieces of sculpture and art. You'll see the waves splashing every so often, whether it's high or low tide.
author: Paul N.

description:
The wave organ is such a hidden gem that I was surprised to find other people there in the middle of the morning on a weekday. True, the couple seemed to be there just to make out in a semi-secluded location and didn't seem to pay any attention to the pipes. But there was one other guy there who asked me what the pipes did and several other people were on their way out to the pier as I was leaving.

It's at the end of the pier in the Marina and the pipes play "music" based on the movement of the ocean. It's best at high tide (8am currently). You have to stick your ear close to the end of the pipe to catch the moaning. There are instructions on a plaque if you forget. 

It's built at several levels with concrete seating. It's pretty sheltered so even if you don't come at the optimal time you can just sit and relax away from the wind.
author: Jean K.

description:
The wave organ is a system of pipes under a small platform which carry the sound of the waves passing through the pipes underneath you to the surface. It's an interesting concept, but it's not as elegant as it sounds. To hear it, you just need to put your head close to the pipes which stick out from the structure. You need to come here at high tide; apparently you have to go at just the right time actually hear anything interesting. I heard some gurgling at one point, but other than that I couldn't hear anything.

The walk to the site itself is probably more interesting than the actual thing. There are some great views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the city skyline, Alcatraz, and boats passing by.
author: Allen C.

description: Fun walk, beautiful sounds ! I came here by night and it was a bit windy, but definitely worth the struggle !
author: Raphael L.

description:
Hidden Gem in San Francisco ! the best views of the Golden gate and the city from the same spot !

Make sure to check High tide times before you make your way there thats when the sounds are best heard... Its serene !
author: Tejshree R.

description:
Nice view... Just that! 

You can see the city skyline, the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz Island. It's a really peaceful place and good to take some pics. 

Unfortunately, It's too small facing the long way you need to cross to get there... It's worth it only if you are already near the area, otherwise don't go just to see the wave organ.

Do some research about the tides, only during high tides you can listen to it!
author: Camila R.

description:
I love the idea and concept of the Wave Organ. I love the brilliance and creativity that enabled someone to conceive it and the DIY ethic that motivated them to turn their vision into reality. Things like this are part of the many things that I love about San Francisco.

That being said, this doesn't quite fulfill its potential as far as being an instrument played by nature. Maybe it did before I started coming here approx. 20 years ago, but the pipes have gotten silted up, so they don't make much of a sound regardless of whether it's high or low tide. Still, you can sometimes hear a bit through the pipes, and it does sound both pleasant and interesting.

What I enjoy most about the Wave Organ is the beautiful view of the Bay and the secluded vantage point that it offers to relax, meditate, and imbibe the wonder of the environment. I've enjoyed many picnics, dates and lazy afternoons here. It's probably illegal, but this would be a great place to smoke a cigar.

This is also a great place to watch the 4th of July fireworks. You have an amazing, panoramic view with no buildings to block your view, but you need to get here very early. Bring lunch and dinner and some warm blankets, and also a friend to hold your space while you trek out to the bathroom and back.
author: Dave C.

description: This is a pretty cool art installation. Know going there that you won't hear a ton of sound but if you sit and listen closely you will get to hear some, which is pretty cool. I recommend going at high tide. I think that is a time of day when you will hear the most. The view is also spectacular. Know going in, it is a bit of a hike to get to it and you won't be rewarded with some intense musical performance but I thought it was a pretty cool idea and worth seeing. It is also very close to the beach so you could tack it into a beach trip.
author: Joanna V.

description:
One of the off the beaten path things to see in SF. 

I honestly love these type of spots. You will have to walk out to this structure and finding parking can be a bishhh...

Once you get here, you can play around and listen to how the water plays the organ. Kinda interesting and cool.
author: Roger A.

description: Maybe I'm missing something here, but Wave Organ doesn't really sound like much of anything. The views of the Golden Gate and Alcatraz are nice and all, but it's kind of a disappointment to be honest.
author: Casey S.

description: Off the beaten bicycle path, but a nice relaxing view of the city with a unique "water music medley" as the waves and organ pipes play.
author: Ted B.

description:
Ok, the wave organ is subtle. I think people would respond more positively to it if it was called something else, as the word organ implies a more musical experience than what is there. 

Also, try to go at high tide. When we got there, about two hours before high tide, we could only hear an occasional gurgle, although my daughter claimed she could hear a high pitched humming from some of the tubes. As it got closer to high tide, the sloshing and gurgling got louder and more musical, but still not what I was expecting.

Nevertheless, this place was so peaceful and playfully ruinous, we ended up staying for 2 hours. Much of that time we were the only ones there, and it was lovely to be alone listing to subtle water noises in the middle of the city.
author: Julie T.

description: This place is beautiful but when I came here with my friends it was low tied so we could not here a single thing. Never the less it is a beautiful spot for pictures and just to hang out and enjoy the view.
author: Sean P.

description: A little bit underwhelming, to say the least. We walked all the way out on the part of the marina where is was located, expect there to be some sort of aural phenomenon that could actually be appreciated. In fact, you had to put your ear up directly to the pipe to hear anything. Maybe it used to be better. Maybe it's better at high tide? Or maybe the idea is only theoretical. I don't know, but what I saw/heard is not really worth coming out here. The best part was some guy who was jumping from rock to rock on a BMX bike. Now that was something.
author: Brent W.

description: Correct me if I'm wrong but I'm pretty sure this thing doesn't work anymore.  Regardless, this is definitely a cute little place to visit.  Sit, enjoy the view, and the company of your friends.  Take some sweet Instagram photos.
author: Jessica F.

description:
This needs to be on your San Francisco bucket list and it needs to be on there now.

Nestled at the end of a quiet, semi-secluded piece of land, the Wave Organ is basically a stone courtyard filled with tubes that accentuate the lapping water from the bay. Listen closely enough or at the right times, and the tubes/pipes actually play tones that sound like an organ. 

Don't come here expecting a symphony. Come here expecting to hear mother nature.  You may hear slurps and "ocean farting", as my brother referred to it, or you may hear tones. In the case of the Wave Organ, beauty is in the eye of the beholder. 

This spot can be appreciated on so many levels. It's got a great view, it's not very touristy and is usually empty, it is peaceful, and it is unique.

I didn't think it was as hard to find as everyone claims. Park at the Yacht Club.  Find the big Rolex clock and face the ocean. Walk to your right (if you look out at the ocean, you walk toward Alcatraz and away from the Golden Gate Bridge). You keep walking behind the Yacht Club along the ocean. It's less than a quarter mile. When you get to the end of the land, the Wave Organ is on the right.

There is a little bench made of stone, and that is the best place to listen to the Wave Organ. 

I can't wait to go back here. Definitely a hidden gem of San Francisco, and truly one of the best kept secrets!
author: T. M.

description:
I only have a few things to say.

One of my biggest regrets is that I reminded myself to check this place out many times over the years of being a native northern Californian and now SF resident for over a decade, but it took me until sometime in the last 2 years to finally make it. I blame some bad reviews (not just from here) that said it's not as cool as you'd think it would be. I think I first saw it featured on Bay Area Back Roads back when Jerry Graham hosted it when I was just a kid back in the Central Valley.

All of those reviews are wrong. It's way cooler than I EVER thought it would be. It's one of those places in San Francisco that I don't want to tell anyone else about, but it just wouldn't be fair to you or to the creators who bestowed this gift unto our lovely city.
author: Myla A.

description: Underwhelming. May have been caused by our high expectations based on other reviews and articles around the web. Really couldn't hear the sounds as clearly as other reviewers claim to. The walk to the sculpture has great views of the Golden Gate Bridge, so if you're looking for a place to take pictures it's worth it. For an interesting and unforgettable SF experience look elsewhere.
author: Aarthi M.

description:
Acoustic excellence.

Above & Beyond's film: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CNUTlKqSO-I

Marina's organ: Interactive art that let's you hear the sound of the waves through a series of pipes. It's calming, beautiful and uniquely San Francisco.

Watch the film. Visit the organ.
author: Jason B.

description:
Who would have thought that I would have so much fun getting chased by monster waves and listening to the ocean through large, curved pipes?  The Wave Organ is a really random local spot in the Marina.  I was a little confused when my host asked if I wanted to go check out "a wave instrument near the Marina".  I had all sorts of weird images in my head when the topic came up, but I trusted my host so we parked in a FREE LOT on Yacht Road, which is a small road so keep your eyes out.  There are two lots and I recommend that you DO NOT park in the one closer to the Yacht Club.  Why?  Well, because like I said...MONSTER WAVES!  Those things smashed up against the walls and flooded the parking lot in a matter of seconds.  Anyone who would have parked in that second lot would have came back to a wet surprise.  The waves were a spectacle and I wish I had a camera to take an artsy shot, but truthfully, I was just having too much fun running and screaming like a kid.

By the time I got to the actual Wave Organ, I was anticipating getting soaked!  Good thing the organ has many different pipes on different levels so you can still enjoy the gurgling sounds of seawater entering old pipes from the top OR you can get pretty close to the water like a bunch of kids did.  Yes, I'm a bigger chicken than these kids.  I didn't wanna get swept away by the current, especially since I have weak swimming skills.  

I probably won't come back to this local attraction for a while unless someone really wants to see it.
author: May W.

description:
This is a cool free outdoor experiential public art exhibit that's fun. 

It pairs especially nice if you are visiting the Yoda Fountain in the Presidio and the Palace of Fine Arts just a looooooooooooooooong block away.

I usually park at Palace of Fine Arts (Free Parking!) and then walk to Yoda and then prepare for the looooooooooong-ass walk to the Wave Organ which is waaaaaaaaaaay the hell at the end.

If someone in your party has a bunion, don't bother, but if the weather is great and you're up for a lively walk along the Bay, then by all means.

The Wave Organ itself is a series of pipes and accoustical effects built into some Gothic stone seats. 

You participate by choosing a place to sit and listening  carefully to the gurgling and spitting sounds of the ocean amplified through a series of giant PVC pipe crazy straws.

It's not quite as cool as you would hope but what the hell, you will seriously want to give them an E for Effort and those gurgling sounds, though not symphonic, certainlly provide a comic effect.
author: Ryan S.

description: Nice walk to here. The wave organ is a system of pipes under a small platform which carry the sound of the waves passing through the pipes underneath you to the surface.
author: Gavin M.

description:
I had been told of the Wave Organ something over a decade ago, and over the years was told the tubes no longer made sounds as they had filled with sediment. 

Finally got to see it recently. It's a nice walk from the St. Francis Yacht Club's parking lot, up the peninsula on which the Wave Organ may be found, past an old-looking, stone light house. Other than the occasional person on one of those bikes rented from Blazing Saddles, we were completely alone. Most of those people turned around before getting to organ, anyway. 

Most of the tubes were completely muted, it seemed. There was nothing but silence even when I held my ear to many of them. Those that did emit sounds were like a trickle of water or like listening to liquids seeping down a drain. Maybe I was there during the wrong time of day? 

Either way, I had fun shouting childish things into the tubes. "Piiiiiiiiiiiiiigs in Spaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaace!" 

It's well-publicized that the Wave Organ is partially constructed from tombstones of previously occupied graves (unclaimed gravemarkers from the days when San Francisco's dead were exhumed and re-buried in Colma have been making appearances on the shore lately: http://www.ktvu.com/news/news/local/beach-erosion-exposes-eerie-relics-san-franciscos-/nPNnk/). I'm not sure if this macabre piece of the organ's history is completely true or just an urban legend. 

The Wave Organ has a pretty sweet 360 view of the city, the Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz, Fort Mason, all the boats drifting by in the bay. We were here on a gloriously clear day when every building looked so crisp and vibrant.
author: Christine A.

description:
I've read about this place from a blogger, then my friend told me it was interesting.  It's not on SF maps so not many people know about it.  It is on the huge map that's at the Hilton Hotel in Chinatown though.

I went here to check it out and also to see the Queen Mary 2 coming over the Golden Gate Bridge.  It's pretty small and the sound it makes sound like a gurgling toilet.

It's near the Golden Gate Yacht Club.

Time visited: 1
author: Ann L.

description:
The view is AWESOME.  It in itself is worth the visit.

The wave organ....  You definitely need to do some research on when is the best time to go and be able to hear something, because i didn't here jack sheeeiiiizy....
author: Steven F.

description:
The Wave Organ is pretty lame, but at the same time it's one of those fantastic San Francisco spots. It was created by a senior artist at the Exploratorium as an art project to capture the sounds of the bay and the waves crashing inside the cement tubes. 

To the left is the Golden Gate Bridge. To the right is Alcatraz. And somewhere in the middle, the crashing waves and sound of the gurgling water in the pipes.

The idea behind it is a bit strange but it's still an intriguing public work. It's the perfect place to listen to nature while enjoying beautiful weather, take an amazing walk along Yacht Blvd and enjoy the beautiful views.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Want to visit a new and refreshing landmark in the city, but the thought of crowded tourist sites gives you the heebie-jeebies? The wave organ might be just the place for you. 

Keep in mind it's small and quaint, but don't let the size fool you. What it lacks in size, it makes up in originality! Who would've thought an organ could be played by the ocean?! Will definitely come back at high tide.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Cool concept, but it didn't work. Perhaps because it wasn't a full high tide.
author: Dana S.

description:
This is one of my favorite 'Local Flavor' spots in San Francisco, it's so unique! A little tricky to find and way further into the marina than I almost ever go, but its really something to see.

Wave organ stuff aside (Yes, yes, you can hear weird underwater noises. Take what you will from that.) I like this place because you have a spectacular view of the bridge, Alcatraz, the marina and even the east bay! It's a quiet little getaway to get some perspective. 

It can be VERY windy, and subsequently cold, but on a warm day I think it's worth it. Definitely a good spot to bring someone you care about. And I''ve heard it's a whole different experience at night!
author: Alyssa G.

description: Cool spot, even if the organ doesn't work anymore.
author: David P.

description:
Disappointing.

Wanting to take my friends to a local spot and reading so many great reviews, we made our trek here with high expectations. Big mistake. All we heard was a gurgling toilet, if anything. 

We had more fun taking jump pictures with the sun setting behind the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Jess C.

description: I visited there for the first time and had the entire site to myself as it was deserted at the time (about 1pm).  It's intriguing, but not mind-blowing.  What other reviewers has said pretty much sums it up.
author: David S.

description:
4 stars for being a neat idea. Basically, there are a bunch of pipes at the end of the jetty, where waves hit some pipes that are partially in the water, creating music like an organ. You put your ear against the section of the pipe that is out of the water to hear the melodic noise. 

-1 star because the noise isn't actually melodic. 

It's a bit difficult to get to...park at the Yacht Club. While facing the Yacht Club from the parking lot, turn right and walk down the street to the very end of the jetty. Walk down the stairs, and there you are!
author: Margaret R.

description:
Ga-bloot...ga-bloot, ga-bloot....whoooosh...ga-bloot....

That's the sound of the water slapping inside the 25 listening pipes that stick out of the granite and marble blocks that make up the Wave Organ. It's a hidden gem of the city and one well worth the surprisingly long stroll to the end of Yacht Road. 

Technically, it's a wave-activated acoustic sculpture, an environmental art piece created by the Exploratorium's Senior Artist-in-Residence Peter Richards and stonemason George Gonzales over two decades ago. I actually wrote about it in my column as a S.F. Travel Examiner. There's also a video clip from a recent feature by Jonathan Mumm of Sacramento's News10. Check it out... 

http://www.examiner.com/x-515-SF-Travel-Examiner~y2008m9d17-The-Wave-Organ-Can-you-hear-the-mermaids-singing

...ga-bloot...ga-bloot, ga-bloot....whoooosh...ga-bloot....
author: Ed U.

description: I din't go during high tide, so I didn't get to hear much and will have to go back sometime when the tide is in.  Still, it's a neat place with a great view and is a little less traveled than some of the other places along the bay.  Next time I have someone in from out of town for a few days I'll have to check the high tide times and bring them here for something off the beaten path.
author: Scott L.

description:
I thought this was a place to dump bodies when we came at night.  If you don't believe me, try coming here at 10 p.m.  or later.  You will not like the water when it looks like a sea of crude oil.  I half expected to see Dexter on Slice of Life cruise by, dropping off neat packages to the ocean floor.

Really pretty during the day, though!  :D  We rode our bikes here.  The presence of tourists (and more importantly, the sun) really brightens things up.
author: Erika C.

description: When my boyfriend told me he was taking me to the wave organ I was expecting to see these large waves crashing against the rocks and listening to melodic noises, like a scene out of The Little Mermaid. When we got there the tide was low so we didn't get to hear much. However, it was a beautiful day and a very quiet spot to soak in the sun and relax. My boyfriend and I spent most of the day staring at the spectacular view and dreaming of owning a sailboat.
author: Cindy A.

description:
I guess it does matter when you come. Like another poster, I was expecting to hear Old Faithful and instead heard the gurgling-toilet sound.
It gets three stars for being kind of weird, haphazard and hard to describe. Kind of like me.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Sad stones, plastic pipes
Why am I wasting time here?
Guess I'm a loser

Just lame blooping sounds
"Wave Organ" right, hahaha
Who pays for this crap?
author: Miles C. H.

description:
While I heard nothing via the listening tubes at the Wave Organ, I still found value in its architectural beauty and self-indulgent photo shoot my boyfriend and I enjoyed there. At first we thought it was located near the Exploratorium but quickly decided to walk to the other end of the jetty on Yacht Road past the San Francisco Yacht Club. With each step, the beach crowd thinned out, leaving only the splash of waves and calls of seagulls. 

The information plaque let me know that the Wave Organ was constructed in 1986 using Gold Rush-era tombstones. The listening tubes comprise PVC pipe. 

The graffiti-adorned bench, winding staircases, architectural charm, and views of the water and Golden Gate Bridge thrilled me on a cold summer day. Apparently 5:30 a.m. is the best time to indulge in Wave Organ music. So maybe next time.
author: Bobbin W.

description:
Not gonna lie, I was a little disappointed. 

That said, I'm sure if I came at 1) high tide or 2) when there weren't so many people, it might have been more awesome. The views are gorgeous though...
author: Natalye R.

description:
To the east of the Golden Gate Bridge, past long lawns of green grass, yacht clubs, and pigeon filled piers sits a special San Francisco monument. A long strip of land curves around the Bay, leading towards a unique natural instrument to play. 

The peninsula's end presents a collection of curiously constructed columns and structures. Peculiar pipes emerge like periscopes from behind the grey granite walls. Carefully carved stones create sheltered seats, surrounding a small courtyard that sinks into the sea. As waves wander through the space starts to perform for you. A symphony of strange sea sounds  sing from each pipe. The unusual notes range from high to low, each pipe gives a mighty blow.  Where can you enjoy unbeatable views of the sea while listening to this interesting harmony?

The one. The only. San Francisco Wave Organ. 

This wondrous  work is a piece of environmental art created by Peter Richards and George Gonzales in 1986. Sponsored by the Exploratorium, this structure was designed to observe and enjoy sounds made by water moving through the space. Built using old cemetery stones and PVC pipes, everything was carefully designed with sea sounds in mind. The result? A masterpiece of physics, engineering and design. And the sound? Is like listening to the largest seashell in the Bay. 

Magical music and breathtaking views, will make a journey out to the Wave Organ worth it for you.  Tourist or not.... you must visit this special stone spot!
author: Caroline J.

description:
The Wave Organ is so unique and just damn cool.  Sure, it doesn't sound like you're in an amazing cathedral listening to an actual organ...but the gurgling, slushing noises have their own beauty and melody...kinda.   If anything it's just a really special spot that is very unknown to like 98% of San Franciscans.  
I love being out on the jetty and feeling kind of cut off from the rest of the city, able to just sit and take in everything from a distance and let my mind wander.
Definitely take people here and woo them with you uber cool knowledge of the unknown spots of SF.  But take your bottles with you when you leave :-)
author: Kevin A.

description:
The whole concept of the structure is splendidly creative.  It's kinda like what you would get if the Blue Man Group could have a baby with Stonehenge.

This place may be somewhat hard-to-reach, but that is part of the reason it is so cool (anticipation is the greatest form of foreplay, teehee).  I couldn't imagine what it would be like if it was out in a place like, say, Fisherman's Wharf.  In the case of the Wave Organ, geography = peace.

I would suggest taking a stroll out along the jetty on a day when the water is choppy.  I went when the weather was a bit too perfect, so the sculpture didn't slap and gurgle as much as I would have liked to enjoy.
author: Jesse M.

description:
The wave organ is one of my favorite places in the whole city. Its so nice to take a detour out there on a sunny day and listen to the lapping waves. Located at the end of the jetty past the Yacht Club (see map), the wave organ provides some outstanding views of the City, as well as being a great curiosity itself. Just go there and have a listen. It cant really be explained. 
Rules: Pack your trash
author: Andrew B.

description: It's a bit tricky to reach this spot but quite a wonder once you get there. The views of both the city and the GG Bridge are quite the sights to behold from this structure. I thought it would be a bit bigger but it's actually just a tiny portion of land that juts into the bay. It truly is a unique experience to hear the "notes" played by the ocean waves and quite a romantic spot for couples-very soothing and relaxing. It's a must-see if you're visiting the city. It's worth the trek!
author: Allison M.

description: This little gem in the city was making sounds gloriously on this sunny Tuesday. They must have recently cleaned out the pipes. I've never heard her sounding so good.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
OK our first stop along the way across the Golden Gate Bridge to Sausalito was this place. 

First off it's almost impossible to find. You make a right on Yacht Road and continue past the Yacht club, pass all the cars, until you are on a small pathway. You continue on out until the very end. Look to your right and that's the "Wave Organ". The day we went it didn't make any sounds and it took almost 40 minutes to finally find this place. It was like a search for gold and all you find are a sack full of pennies. 

It does offer some nice views but this view can be seen from anywhere around this area.
author: David N.

description: this was a realy cool place. I suggested that me and my mom visit it because it sounded interesting. She had been to san francisco many times and never been there. It wasnt that bad of a walk from the yacht club. We were there a little before high tide and the sound was quite loud when you were sitting next to the tubes. One actually scared my mom because of how loud it was an the sound it made. The views are always amazing. Its a nice place to visit and relax in san francisco. I would recommend it to all to check out.
author: haley b.

description:
What's in the Marina and promises to blow but doesn't?  If you said the "Wave organ" you'd get one nice big shiny gold star, which is exactly what this place gets from me.

The wave organ's just a bunch of pipes that run into the water and untold generations of San Franciscan's have been delighted by this little pilgrimage to, well, that, but you might have a better rap if you just take a couple of glasses up to your ears and wobble them back and forth really fast instead.  

Don't get me wrong, the general ambience of the place and the walk out to the jetty is fantastical so dig that.  The views are stellar (which is why the yacht club took it) and on a nice day just lounge about cat-like, if you can find a comfortable spot in a sunbeam of appropriate wattage.
author: Jim W.

description:
This is a great place to sit when you have a lot on your mind.  The sound of the organ is something that is kind of hard to explain because it is different depending on the time of day you show up...maybe you'll have a variety of slurps, or maybe ocean burps, or maybe ocean whirls, it just depends on where the tide is and how much wave activity you have.  There is a small alcove that I recommend sitting in for a bit - there are some small, amplified pipes that feed directly into the alcove and echo and mash-up into a strange symphony of sounds.  

Not the most exciting thing to do with a group of friends, but wonderful to do on your own if you are having a day where you're in the mood for some solitude.
author: Rachel G.

description:
The Wave Organ is one of those cool San Francisco spots that always makes me feel good to visit. Situated on the end of the peninsula that SFYC is on it's a great place to watch the whatever might be going on in the bay. 
 Years ago when I was here with my girlfriend (Who would later become my wife) we watched a submarine surface from this place. You never know what you'll see if you hang around long enough.
author: Steve N.

description: Reliable date spot, even better at night.
author: Inigo M.

description:
The Wave Organ sounds more grandiose than it is in reality. If you think there are going to be massive waves crashing all around you producing symphonic organ music well, then sure, you're going to be a little disappointed. However, if you're looking for a primordial, guttural thunking sound or the amplified musings of a tapped out toilet then you, my friend, are in for quite a treat.  I suppose it would be presumptuous to expect a free form Jethro Tull jam session but a guy can dream.

Besides the less than impressive acoustics of the Wave Organ just look around you, dude. Situated on a tiny slip of a peninsula on the bay it's constructed out of what appears to be collected bits of old stonework. The view is panoramic and, if it wasn't for those goddamned pipes, is really quite serene. Just bring your own Jethro Tull.
author: Josua P.

description: For some reason, I always end up at the Wave Organ at night.  Despite it always being freezing, there's definitely something about this place that helps my brain think a little bit better.  It's a nice place to sit extra close to someone and have long, deep conversations while listening to the "slurps" and the fog horn in the background. The view is an extra bonus.
author: Helen V.

description: Not as cool as you would think. Plaque says works best during full moon, so make sure you go during a full moon, otherwise don't waste your time.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I really enjoyed the wave organ, although the tide wasn't such where I could here any audible "wave music". However, it was very peaceful and tranquil. 

A few things.. 

I was thrown off a little by the location since I used the Yelp map as a reference. So here are the CORRECT DIRECTIONS: 

Once you make a right on Lyon/ Yacht Rd continue around the bend and find parking.  Walk to the very end of the peninsula which is where you will find the organ. You have to pass the Yacht Club on your left and further down there's another bldg. on your right hand side.  Once you pass that, it's a short walk.
author: Eclectic C.

description: It's really fun and an amazing view out to the bridge. There can be a fish smell from time to time but it is the ocean. Its' fun to hang and listen to the sounds from the tubes and note some are better than others.
author: Eisa m.

description:
I guess I had bad timing. Couldn't hear anything from the wave organs, but the place is just bizarre :) 

Worth a visit, to see them
author: Manish P.

description:
Either I have...

Bad timing

or

I'm deaf

Because every time I come out here, the only thing I hear are seagulls.

It is a nice spot to come and sit and reflect...

reflect on WHY THE HELL I NEVER HEAR THE DAMN ORGAN!!!!

*sigh*
author: Christy L.

description: Pretty underwhelming actually. The views of the city and bridge are nice, but the organ itself was kind of disappointing.
author: Mike D.

description:
Awesome outdoor art!  Beautiful scenery and cool concept. This video gives a great overview of the project! 

 http://www.monkeysee.com/play/21811-the-san-francisco-bay-makes-its-own-music
author: Amanda V.

description:
Despite all the foot traffic and lack of privacy in this calm setting... the 360 degree view is outstanding!! (...that is if you're standing) 

This spot has become my favorite place to just kick back and take a load off. I highly recommend checking this place out (although it's a tad hard to find) 

:-)
author: Tedi O.

description:
"Ga-bloot...ga-bloot, ga-bloot....whoooosh...ga-bloo t...."

This I gotta see [OOPS!  I mean hear].

[queue the band]  Goin' to San Francisco -- the end of this month.  Gonna go see/hear the Wave Organ.  Just gotta.  Just gotta.

Review to follow in December.
author: Charlie G.

description:
The Wave organ is a fine excuse to hang out by the sea on a nice day.

I heard some cool sounds, too.
author: Quinn G.

description:
One of the coolest out-of-the-way things in Marina.  Despite it's location being totally visible from anywhere on Marina Green, suprisingly few know about it.

Wait for a less-windy day though if you want to stay warm - it gets chilly with the bay winds.
author: Rob K.

description:
The Wave Organ doesn't work as well as it used to but it is an excellent place to show off your astounding SF knowledge to a friend and/or date. Grab a six pack o' your favorite bevvy and ViBe out to the sweet, sweet sounds of the lapping waves through odd tubes made of submerged tombstones and piping! 

Then go get tanked or what not.
author: Cliff C.

description:
I have to admit, I was really stuck between giving it three or four stars... I ended up going with four and giving it the benefit of the doubt, because, really... it's unique.

I'll agree with those before me that the sounds emanating from the Wave Organ didn't really move me to write Romantic poetry... maybe a limmerick... but it is no Aeolian harp.

But for all that the Wave Organ isn't,  it IS a rather cool structure in a well hidden niche at the end of a jetty in the SF bay!  And that in itself should make you want to check it out.  (Just don't expect mermaids singing.)
author: Lisa W.

description:
The Wave Organ is an animated musical environmental art installation that is powered by the Bay. Who new that PVC tubing could be so much fun? It's a great destination for the times when you find yourself at the Marina Green at 6:00 am. You see, it puts on the best show at high tide. Rumor is that the tubes may be a little congested now but the last time I was there (at 6:00 am) it was happily gurgling. Check the NOAA tide tables and your drug intake half life accordingly.

http://wolfweb.unr.edu/homepage/edc/tides/2007/sfgg_fr07.html
author: Harland K.

description: Great little spot without the usual hoards of tourists...  Worth finding and listen to the music of the tide.  Lovely view of the city and bridge.  Perfect place to bring a picnic and enjoy every aspect of your surroundings.  Oh yes, best to go during a high tide as the sound is much better!
author: Leslie G.

description:
The first time I came out here was one dark night and I thought where the hell are we going?  Seriously?  Where?  And why am I following this nut?  Then all of a sudden he turns to me and says, "sshh, listen"  WHAT THE HECK ... I was from Tex-Ass and it was soo 'interesting' soo cool that when I tried explaining it to friends back home, they're like "sea organ pipes, ok". 

Well, I'm also finding out that apparently not alot of folks here know about this place because when I ask, they're like "What?"  

So, this is a real nice hidden gem for the curious!
author: Stel D.

description: I visited this place on 16-Sep-2009 around 8:30 morning. It had no clean up or maintenance at all. It is dirty and smelly. Two guys finishing at the end of the pier. One guy was peeing on the spot. Cannot hear any sound except some water splashing on PVC pipe sound. You can hear that by dipping PVC pipe into a bucket of water. Although the view of Golden Gate Bridge, Alcatraz and city are nice from here, but it is not worth for the walk. See the photos I attached (If I able to figure out how to upload photo at here).
author: YF S.

description:
This took me forever to find. I had heard rumors for along time and finally I was sick and tired of hearing about it so I went on a urban sherpa-like trek from the Mission to the Marina. I walked along the yacht club parking lots until I found it.

The organ is sort of smallish, I think I was expecting something bigger and more musical like. But nevertheless, it was worth it. It is the type of thing that makes me so happy to live in SF. It is special, unique, weird and haphazard - a great night time adventure, date sort of place!

*and yes it sounds much like a toilet so get over it people
author: Shannon Z.

description: It's actually pretty hard to find this place since it's at the end of the Yacht Road past all the boats and yacht clubs. It's pretty windy and mostly deserted. Sometimes people come here to go fishing but the main purpose is to listen to the tube holes for different chords produced by the waves. It's pretty interesting to hear the contrast in each tube. Even though it was recently renovated, it looks like trash since there's graffiti and cement waste thrown everywhere. On occasion, you will see small crabs roaming at the bottom where the waves meet the cement. Be careful when the tide starts to rise during high-tide!
author: Dominic T.

description:
I LOVE that other people know about the wave organ! Of course, I knew I wasn't the only one but no one else in my various circles of aquaintances, friends, coworkers etc knows about it. 

The tide has to be high to hear all the sounds, but either way it's an amazing places. In my opinion, the concept alone is pretty damn cool. Clear nights are my favorite time to go.
author: Risa R.

description:
I originally thought this would have been a fun spot for a second date but after trekking out there by myself this afternoon, I think it's safe to say that I would have been kinda completely creeped out to go all the way out there at night. WHAT IF GIANT SEA MONSTERS GET ME???

But hey...during the day, it's a scenic walk and there were a couple of small and un-walked-upon beaches on either side of that little peninsula and I thought that it would be a beautiful spot to park my ass on a sunny day. The wave organ itself was also a nice place to park my ass. Or, it would have been except there was a lady sleeping or something and since the wave organ isn't all that big (size DOES matter, BTW) I felt awkward hanging out next to an anonymous sleeper so I sat around on a bench-like thing adjacent to the wave organ instead. 

So anyway, the organ itself was cool-ish. Not for it's organ-ness, but because it was like a secret spot out in the middle of nowhere -slash- in the middle of a huge metropolitan area. Like other reviewers have suggested, I imagine it would be really cool at night, but I'm entirely too much of a wuss to find out.
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Rode mopeds here w/ a couple of friends one night. Tides weren't high enough to make any sound though WAH :(
author: Hana G.

description:
Eerie, really.

Those are people's gravestones that have been thrown together haphazardly!!  I think even the benches are made of former tombstones.  

So bizarre and you have to see it!
author: Femita J.

description: I had very high expectations for the Wave Organ and must say that I was disappointed.  The idea is cool especially since it's so hidden but the actual sounds were nothing to write home about.  There are other San Francisco "secrets" that I would recommend over this.
author: Blake B.

description:
The story behind this place is both creepy and beautiful.  An awesome sound experiment that when caught at the right time provides for a skin crawling good time.

Make sure you do check the tide times.  High tide is the best time to go.

Bring a loved one, a bottle of something savory, and maybe a blanket.  A unique sound experience and awesome bay, bridge, and lighthouse views can be found here.
author: Augie S.

description:
I love the wave organ! You have to make sure the tide is high in order to hear the full range of sounds. I went with a friend and he hated, but I loved it! It's such a cool idea and has a great view of the city at night.


p.s. Great place for a night adventure date.
author: Javier B.

description:
In order to really experience it you have to be there really early in the morning, but most of us just aren't up then! As long as you recognize that it's not really an "organ" and the sounds aren't going to be loud unless there are a lot of waves, you'll enjoy yourself.

What I love about it is that, even on a warm afternoon, it's usually not too crowded. Lots of great views in addition that you can enjoy even more because it's in such a unique environment!
author: Rachael E.

description:
The Wave Organ needs an action committe to raise funds to repair it, because when it is operational it is DOPE! I first learned of it long before I moved to SF, on a PBS program back in Philly with the creator. I thought the concept of a perpetual sound/music creation generator in nature was really cool.
