( i was doing experimental music at the time). Anyway, when I first moved to SF one of the first things I tracked down was the Wave Organ.

Its at the tippy tip end of a think strip of land opposite the Marina Green. you can ony get to ti by driving in toward the SF Yacht Club or Harbor Club, etc... it's a cool little walk out there, a nice view -- but the magic is/was, when the sound was happening.

The problem now, is that so many people know about and that spot has been a hang now for beer drinking and vandalism, that its in bad disrepair. There are tubes, columns/pipes that emerge all around the sculpture garden. People have thrown trash and stuff down there clogging it up. As well, after 25 or more years, there are cracks in the concrete tubes that go out in the water, and I suspect things are growing inside. It needs a gian Roter-Rooter-ing. Most people think its just a matter of Low Tide, but it's not. When the thing was fully working, you didn't even have to lean your ear in to tube. You could just sit and stand in the sculpture area and it was amazing. It doesn't merely make rusing water gurgly sounds. I've heard sounds that sounded like Bass being plucked, voices, clarinet and guitar amongst others... probably 15 or so years ago I brought my grandmother there and it was high tide and it was working really nicely... I still enjoy just being there, but between fishermen skunking it up and vandals it needs some work... still worth checking out though! And its FREE.
author: R A.

description: Very cool spot.  Great little nook to sit in and enjoy the view and be serenaded by the gentle sounds of the 'organ'.   It's almost like a little secret spot in San Francisco.  Turn around and enjoy a view of the entire Golden Gate Bridge (when it's not foggy).
author: Denise M.

description: You can't go to the Wave Organ expecting to hear a symphony because that's just not how it works. But if you come at high tide (last night at 10:30 worked out pretty perfectly), you will be able to hear the difference in tones that each pipe can make when the waves are hitting it. You can also sit in the stereo booth, smoke a bowl and listen to the reflection of sound through the holes in the stone wall. I suggest go with a friend that can appreciate it, enjoy the scenery and the sound which I can only describe as calm and serene.
author: Megan P.

description: The Wave Organ is an installation piece at the end of the jetty past the St. Francis Yacht club that's comprised of a number of  marble seating alcoves made from an old cemetery (it sounds creepy, but it's actually quite restful).  The artist partially submerged the ends of large organ pipes in the water with the other ends protruding from the alcoves at various intervals.  If you put your ear to the pipes you can hear the distorted lapping of the waves.  This is a great place to read, take a date, or reflect on how lucky you are to live in San Francisco.
author: Kevin G.

description:
we visited the wave organ this afternoon & it was a great, off-the-beaten-path attraction for san francisco. it does take a keen eye to find it, but it really isn't THAT hard. find the yacht club. walk past the yacht club. do not walk into the water. then you will find the wave organ. sure, there aren't any neon signs or arrows pointing to it, but it's sort of tucked away like a nice little treasure.

if you don't go at high tide, don't expect to hear much - we were there around noon & could only hear some very bass-y splashes/booms from the small waves, but the construction of the organ itself is pretty awesome. we sat & took photos for about twenty minutes, then went on our merry way. it was a nice, relaxing break from the craziness of the city.
author: Jenn S.

description: It's alright. It makes a gargle noise. For me it was just a nice, wind-protected place to sit and watch the sail boats out on the bay.
author: Bryan E.

description: Oh wave organ, how I love you for providing such great foreplay!
author: Colleen B.

description: No, these mysterious ruins aren't built by Druids for some arcane baptismal ritual.  This is a sound project by the SF Exploratorium.  Sit on the "bench" and hear the slaps, gurgles, burps and bwoooop! of the SF Bay.   I agree with Kevin G.  --secret little mystical places like these make you feel great about being a San Franciscan.  I myself discovered this place on my gallivants as a young urban SF high schooler.  Am I cheapening the secret legacy (well, it's not as much secret, as little-known)?  I want to share. YELP!
author: Marjorie B.

description: The wave organ is some bullshit.  Doesn't make much sound anymore.
author: Cully W.

description: The best time to visit is when the tide is out. Or maybe when the tide is in. I can't remember, but everytime I go, it is a magical experience. Bloot!
author: Mitsi M.

description: The Wave Organ is one of my all time favorite places in the world. In the WORLD. It seems some reviewers find the burblings and gluggings of the water in the organ pedestrian, but I never fail to be amazed by their variety and uniqueness.  Plus, I love the fact that it was constructed from the remains of a Gold Rush-era cemetary near the city. It's a wonderful place to picnic, smooch, and watch the sailboats.
author: Esther H.

description: After reading about the wave organ and bookmarking it on Yelp, I finally saw it today! Very pretty and interesting installation. Unfortunately, there were not much waves today hence no loud sounds from the pipes but the views from this point is just amazing. But something eerie about it as other Yelpers pointed out, some stones were taken from the graveyard of a cemetary that was being moved or closed down.
author: Yan M.

description: It's hard to find, can't really hear the "music", and last time I was there, there were these teenagers being loud and annoying. Hopefully next time I visit, I'll hear the music.
author: Janice F.

description: This is not a bad place to visit if you have ran out of places to visit in the city.  The fact that the place was partially built with tombstones creeped me out a little.   There was a black & white picture of a parent and a child.  I'm pretty sure it's not a real photograph of dead persons.  But still.... *shudders* Interesting looking pipes.  All I heard was not the waves, but the water hitting the metal pipes.  I went on a foggy day, so the view wasn't that great.  I will love to visit there again on a sunny day if the painting is erased.  Eeek.
author: Jessica N.

description: Growing up in San Francisco I frequented the Wave Organ to drink 40's and listen to the waves, but now I still go to have a nice quiet moment late at night when I need to pretend that I don't live in a major city.  Also a really great place to go after a romantic dinner with your honey.
author: Cassie L.

description: yeah... i don't get this place either.  it was interesting, the organ and all.  maybe the tide was low and i couldn't hear much?  maybe we were in such a rush to take a picture and keep on biking to marin that we couldn't appreciate its serenity?  yeah that's it.  but it's cool we stopped by.  it's marked on the biking trail map from one of those bike the gg bridge and return by ferry deals.
author: Em C.

description: It's a very pretty place. The organ doesn't really play that well any more, as it's about 20 years old. To quote SF Weekly, it's more of a visual curiosity. I think it's worth seeing, though I wouldn't bring kids as they usually want to paddle & there are signs that warn of hazardous water.
author: Caroline B.

description: The wave organ was ok. After having lived here for several months, I realized I have walked and jogged in the marina area, but had never stopped at the Wave Organ. It is a little out of the way, but it is worth visiting at least once. I didn't visit during high tide, so I may have to go back. But there are great views from here to take pictures of the bridge, the little patches of sand on either side of the jetty, and the organ itself.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
I went there about 2 weeks ago with my friend. I found out about it here on YELP.. or maybe Googling for a picture. Anyways, the place was pretty awesome. We went on a really beautiful day.. it was warm with a nice breeze and no clouds. Being there felt like we weren't in the city. The place has a nice view of the city and of the Golden Gate Bridge.

And about the organs, it was so cool sounding and relaxing.. and funny for some reason. 

The area over all is just a really chill place to relax .. perhaps some "reflection time" to yourself.  

Like Cade P. said, it's kind of a secret place and something you would never really expect to find.
author: Mila B.

description: 15 years ago you could hear it almost every time a wave hit. Haven't been in a long long time but I'm going with a friend from Colorado next month.  Hope it is the unique wonderful only in SF experience I remember!  All you one stars should contact the GGNRA or park and Rec of SF and see if something can be done about maintaining the wave organ, instead of just complaining.  Have you ever been to another one........Peace
author: Jennifer S.

description: Fucking impossible to find.  No signs anywhere???  Not as cool as I'd hoped.  I guess that's what I get for having high expectations.  Pretty nice view, I suppose.  Maybe it would be better at night...
author: Green T.

description: Back in high school, my friends and I would cross over the Bay Bridge at all hours to chill here. Now that I'm older and soberer and more apt to visit during the daytime it has a different vibe, but it's still a cool/weird spot. Just when I thought I would never find myself in the Marina again.
author: Megan S.

description:
the wave organ is a neat concept with a nice setup.  but i think i may have gone when the tide was low, because i didn't hear much in terms of interesting soundwaves.  i might consider venturing out again to give it another listen, but i'd wear sneakers the next time around.

marble seating was neat though.  and the views of the bay were pretty too.
author: spiff e.

description: I love to walk out here from my house. It's fun to sit and hear the low gurgling of the Bay, like it's trying to talk to you.
author: Anna B.

description: Gem indeed! Now if only someone would do something similar to the sound garden in Washington.. that way during low tide there'll be something else to listen to... and in the AM hours it'd be a Wave&Wind Orchestra!!! MWAHAHAHAHA!
author: Eugene G.

description: There is a reason this place is a secret. It's a huge disappointment once you find it.  I read about the Peter Richard's Wave Organ when I picked up a copy of art-SITES San Francisco from Zinc Details on Fillmore, and was in total aw and had to go at once.  I asked my San Francisco native roommate if he had ever been. He said no, so I thought "wow this would be so awesome if not many people know about this place". It could be a douchebag free haven to sit and relax and enjoy the Wave Organ's awsomeness! Not the case. After following art-SITES detailed directions, my roommate and I almost gave up hope, but alas we found the not so glorious Wave Organ.   Take a gander for yourself, but I think you'll be disappointed.
author: Joseph M.

description: I've always been disappointed every time I've made the trek out here - even at the "right" time during high tide...
author: Quartknee K.

description: great piece of earth art! unfortunately i think the pipes are clogged with barnacles and whatnot. i wish the city maintained it! a beautiful and zany destination to bike to.
author: Nicky T.

description: a gem.  kooky.  it's always a treat to go when the weather's just right so you can actually hear the sounds coming out.  a great place for views and photos.  friends from out of town love it.  in my younger days, i'd go at night.  now ... it's a great place for a walk with the dog and hopefully will always be.
author: cheryl f.

description: best secret place in San Francisco to picnic on a work day
author: Sarah N.

description: It's pretty hard to imagine something more wonderful than the Wave Organ.  I went to it for the first time last week and went back the next night.  It's sort of hard to find, especially at night and half drunk, but if you have faith in the wave organ, you'll find it.  Second of all, its not exactly a great geological achievement to put tubes in water and hear the waves.  However, its a great thing to be among the bay with a view of the city, both bridges, with some friends, maybe a flask of rum, or whatever keeps you warm.  There are benches and seating areas around the tubes, and the space if big enough so that if you and your friend are marvelling at the awesomeness of our city by the bay, and a couple come by who want to catch some face time, you don't disturb each other too much.  As far as the actual wave organ, its neat.  You can hear the water.  Its much better at high tide.  I personally recommend the two tubes down closest to the water, especially the one on the left.  So, great for a date, great for friends, great for smoking herb, great for solemn relfection.  Just one of those things that can warm your heart as you freeze your face off in this San Fran Cisco of ours.
author: Mike C.

description: Lame to everyone who reviewed this. I think its very nice to want to share one of the city's best kept secrets with some close friends, but putting info about it online is only going to draw more attention to this fabulous spot. It will no longer be a cool secret place because everyone will know about it. Disappointed.
author: katie g.
